home.title: ADHD Assessment Platform
home.subtitle: Comprehensive assessment tools to help understand attention, focus, and impulse control patterns

whatIsAdhd.title: What is ADHD?
whatIsAdhd.description: Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) is a neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by persistent patterns of inattention, hyperactivity, and impulsivity that interfere with functioning or development. ADHD affects both children and adults and can impact various aspects of daily life including work, school, relationships, and self-esteem.

inattention.title: Inattention
inattention.description: Difficulty sustaining attention, following through on tasks, organizing activities, and being easily distracted by external stimuli.

hyperactivity.title: Hyperactivity
hyperactivity.description: Excessive fidgeting, restlessness, difficulty staying seated, and feeling the need to be constantly in motion.

impulsivity.title: Impulsivity
impulsivity.description: Acting without thinking, interrupting others, difficulty waiting turns, and making hasty decisions without considering consequences.

statistics.title: ADHD Statistics & Facts
statistics.childrenWorldwide: of children worldwide are diagnosed with ADHD
statistics.adultsEstimated: of adults are estimated to have ADHD
statistics.symptomsIntoAdulthood: of children with ADHD continue to have symptoms into adulthood
statistics.maleToFemaleRatio: ratio of males to females diagnosed with ADHD in childhood

commonComorbidities.title: Common Comorbidities
commonComorbidities.description: ADHD often co-occurs with other conditions including anxiety disorders (25-40%), depression (20-30%), learning disabilities (20-30%), and oppositional defiant disorder.

geneticFactors.title: Genetic Factors
geneticFactors.description: ADHD has a strong genetic component with heritability estimated at 70-80%. If a parent has ADHD, their child has a 25-35% chance of also having ADHD.

questionnaire.title: Questionnaire Assessment
questionnaire.description: Complete the 18-question ADHD assessment questionnaire to screen for symptoms.

cpt.title: CPT-3 Assessment
cpt.description: Conners Continuous Performance Test - objective measurement of attention and impulse control.

features.measures: Measures sustained attention and response inhibition

tova.title: TOVA Assessment
tova.description: Test of Variables of Attention - measures attention and impulse control with geometric shapes.

aboutAssessments.title: About the Assessments
aboutAssessments.intro: This platform provides multiple evidence-based assessment tools for ADHD screening and evaluation. Each method has its own strengths and limitations, and none should be used as a standalone diagnostic tool.

questionnaire.title: Questionnaire Assessment
questionnaire.purpose: Purpose: This 18-question self-report screening tool is designed to identify symptoms consistent with ADHD in adults. It assesses both inattentive and hyperactive-impulsive symptoms across different life domains. The questionnaire is divided into two parts: Part A (first 6 questions) focuses on the most predictive symptoms for ADHD screening, while Part B (remaining 12 questions) provides additional clinical information.
limitations: Screening tool only, not a diagnostic instrument
May not capture all ADHD symptoms or subtypes
Subjective responses can vary based on self-awareness

cpt.title: CPT-3 Assessment
cpt.purpose: Purpose: The Conners Continuous Performance Test 3rd Edition (CPT-3) is a computerized assessment that objectively measures attention and impulse control. During the 14-minute test, participants respond to target letters while inhibiting responses to non-targets. The test evaluates sustained attention, response inhibition, vigilance, and consistency of performance over time.
limitations: May not detect all ADHD subtypes equally well
Performance can be influenced by factors other than ADHD (fatigue, motivation, anxiety, etc.)
Not a standalone diagnostic tool - requires clinical interpretation
Requires proper administration conditions and environment

tova.title: TOVA Assessment
tova.purpose: Purpose: The Test of Variables of Attention (TOVA) is a computerized continuous performance test that measures attention and impulse control using simple geometric shapes. The test consists of two halves: the first half presents infrequent targets to assess attention when targets are rare, while the second half presents frequent targets to assess impulse control when non-targets are rare.
limitations: Can produce false positives or false negatives
Performance can vary based on environmental factors and distractions
Not sufficient alone for diagnosis - should be combined with other assessments
May be affected by practice effects if repeated

disclaimer.title: ⚠️ Important Disclaimer
disclaimer.text: These assessments are screening tools and should not replace professional medical evaluation. A comprehensive ADHD diagnosis requires clinical assessment by a qualified healthcare professional, including medical history, physical examination, and consideration of multiple information sources. If you have concerns about ADHD, please consult with a healthcare provider.

otherAssessments.title: Other ADHD Assessment Tools
otherAssessments.intro: While this platform focuses on specific assessments, there are many other validated tools used in ADHD evaluation. The following are some commonly used assessments that are not currently available on this platform:

conners.name: Conners Rating Scales (CRS):
conners.description: Comprehensive rating scales for parents, teachers, and self-report. Available in multiple versions (Conners 3, Conners CBRS) for different age groups.

vanderbilt.name: Vanderbilt Assessment Scales:
vanderbilt.description: Parent and teacher rating scales commonly used in pediatric settings to assess ADHD symptoms and related impairments.

adhdrs.name: ADHD Rating Scale (ADHD-RS):
adhdrs.description: Standardized rating scale based on DSM criteria, available in versions for children and adults.

asrs.name: Adult ADHD Self-Report Scale (ASRS):
asrs.description: WHO-developed screening tool for adult ADHD, available in both full and abbreviated versions.

badds.name: Brown Attention-Deficit Disorder Scales (BADDS):
badds.description: Comprehensive assessment focusing on executive function deficits associated with ADHD.

baars.name: Barkley Adult ADHD Rating Scale (BAARS):
baars.description: Self-report and observer rating scales specifically designed for adult ADHD assessment.

wurs.name: Wender Utah Rating Scale (WURS):
wurs.description: Retrospective self-report scale assessing childhood ADHD symptoms in adults.

snap.name: SNAP Rating Scale:
snap.description: Swanson, Nolan, and Pelham rating scale for assessing ADHD symptoms and related behaviors.

iva2.name: IVA-2 (Integrated Visual and Auditory CPT):
iva2.description: Continuous performance test that measures both visual and auditory attention, providing comprehensive assessment of attention deficits.

qbtest.name: QbTest:
qbtest.description: Computerized test combining attention and activity measurement using infrared motion tracking to assess hyperactivity.

tea.name: Test of Everyday Attention (TEA):
tea.description: Battery of tests assessing different aspects of attention including selective, sustained, and divided attention.

dkefs.name: Delis-Kaplan Executive Function System (D-KEFS):
dkefs.description: Comprehensive assessment of executive functions including working memory, cognitive flexibility, and inhibition.

brief.name: Behavior Rating Inventory of Executive Function (BRIEF):
brief.description: Rating scale assessing executive function behaviors in daily life, available for children and adults.

kcpt.name: Conners Kiddie Continuous Performance Test (K-CPT):
kcpt.description: Age-appropriate version of the CPT designed specifically for children ages 4-5.

stroop.name: Stroop Color-Word Test:
stroop.description: Classic neuropsychological test measuring cognitive inhibition and selective attention.

trail.name: Trail Making Test:
trail.description: Assessment of visual attention, task switching, and processing speed, commonly used in ADHD evaluations.

otherAssessments.note: Note: This list represents only a sample of available ADHD assessment tools. A comprehensive ADHD evaluation typically involves multiple assessment methods, clinical interviews, behavioral observations, and consideration of developmental history. The choice of assessment tools depends on the individual's age, specific concerns, and the clinical context. Always consult with qualified healthcare professionals for proper assessment and diagnosis.

inattentive.title: Predominantly Inattentive (ADHD-I)
inattentive.description: Characterized primarily by difficulties with attention and focus, with fewer hyperactive or impulsive symptoms.

hyperactive.title: Predominantly Hyperactive-Impulsive (ADHD-H)
hyperactive.description: Characterized by hyperactivity and impulsivity, with fewer inattentive symptoms.

combined.title: Combined Type (ADHD-C)
combined.description: The most common subtype, featuring significant symptoms of both inattention and hyperactivity-impulsivity.
features: Meets criteria for both inattention and hyperactivity

childhood.title: Childhood & Adolescence
symptoms: Academic difficulties, poor grades despite intelligence
Social challenges and peer relationship difficulties

genetic.title: Genetic Factors
genetic.description: ADHD has a strong genetic component with heritability estimated at 70-80%. If a parent has ADHD, their child has a 25-35% chance of also having ADHD.
points: Family history is a significant risk factor
Multiple genes are involved, not a single gene
Genetic variations affect neurotransmitter systems

environmental.title: Environmental Factors
environmental.description: While genetics play the primary role, certain environmental factors may contribute to ADHD risk.
points: Premature birth or low birth weight
Prenatal exposure to alcohol, tobacco, or drugs
Lead exposure in early childhood
Brain injuries

medication.title: Medication
medication.description: Medications can be effective in managing ADHD symptoms, but should always be prescribed and monitored by a healthcare professional.
types: Antidepressants: Sometimes used for comorbid conditions
medication.note: Medication effectiveness varies by individual and should be part of a comprehensive treatment plan.

therapy.title: Therapy & Behavioral Interventions
therapy.description: Various therapeutic approaches can help individuals develop coping strategies and improve functioning.
types: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT): Addresses thought patterns and behaviors
Behavioral Therapy: Focuses on modifying behaviors and developing skills
Parent Training: Helps parents support children with ADHD
Social Skills Training: Improves interpersonal relationships
Executive Function Coaching: Develops organization and planning skills

myths.title: Common Myths vs. Facts
myths: "ADHD is caused by bad parenting or too much sugar"
"ADHD only affects children and they grow out of it"
"People with ADHD just need to try harder"
facts: ADHD is a neurobiological condition with strong genetic components
ADHD persists into adulthood for 60% of those diagnosed in childhood
ADHD involves real brain differences that affect executive function
When properly prescribed and monitored, ADHD medications are safe and effective
ADHD is recognized by major medical organizations worldwide

gettingHelp.title: Getting Help and Support

professional.title: Professional Resources
resources: Consult with a psychiatrist, psychologist, or neurologist specializing in ADHD
Seek comprehensive evaluation including clinical interview and assessment tools
Work with therapists trained in ADHD-specific interventions
Consider ADHD coaches for practical skill development

support.title: Support Networks
resources: Join ADHD support groups (in-person or online)
Educate family and friends about ADHD

gettingHelp.remember: Remember: Early diagnosis and appropriate treatment can significantly improve quality of life. If you suspect you or a loved one may have ADHD, don't hesitate to seek professional evaluation. With proper support, individuals with ADHD can thrive and succeed in all areas of life.

medications.title: ADHD Medications
medications.intro: Medication can be an effective component of ADHD treatment when prescribed and monitored by a qualified healthcare professional. This section provides information about common ADHD medications, their mechanisms, and important considerations.

disclaimer.title: ⚠️ Important Medical Disclaimer
disclaimer.text: The information provided here is for educational purposes only and should not replace professional medical advice, diagnosis, or treatment. Always consult with a qualified healthcare provider before starting, stopping, or changing any medication. Only licensed healthcare professionals can prescribe ADHD medications after a proper evaluation.

stimulants.title: Stimulant Medications
stimulants.description: Stimulants are the most commonly prescribed medications for ADHD and are considered first-line treatment. They work by increasing the levels of certain neurotransmitters (dopamine and norepinephrine) in the brain, which helps improve attention, focus, and impulse control.

methylphenidate.title: Methylphenidate-Based Medications
methylphenidate.description: These medications are available in various formulations with different durations of action.
medications: Daytrana (patch): Transdermal patch, provides consistent delivery
Focalin / Focalin XR: Dexmethylphenidate, similar to methylphenidate
Quillivant XR / Quillichew ER: Liquid and chewable formulations

amphetamine.title: Amphetamine-Based Medications
amphetamine.description: These medications also increase dopamine and norepinephrine, with slightly different mechanisms.
medications: Adderall / Adderall XR: Mixed amphetamine salts, immediate and extended-release
Vyvanse (lisdexamfetamine): Prodrug that converts to dextroamphetamine, long-acting
Dexedrine / Dexedrine Spansule: Dextroamphetamine, immediate and extended-release
Mydayis: Triple-bead delivery system, lasts up to 16 hours

stimulants.note: Note: Stimulant medications are controlled substances and require careful monitoring. Common side effects may include decreased appetite, sleep difficulties, headaches, and increased heart rate or blood pressure. These medications should not be used by individuals with certain heart conditions, glaucoma, or a history of substance abuse.

nonStimulants.title: Non-Stimulant Medications
nonStimulants.description: Non-stimulant medications may be preferred when stimulants are not suitable, cause intolerable side effects, or when there are concerns about abuse potential. They work through different mechanisms than stimulants.

atomoxetine.title: Atomoxetine (Strattera)
atomoxetine.description: A selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI) that is not a controlled substance.
points: Takes 2-4 weeks to see full effects
Once-daily dosing
May help with anxiety symptoms
Common side effects: nausea, fatigue, decreased appetite
May cause liver problems in rare cases

alpha2.title: Alpha-2 Agonists
alpha2.description: These medications work by affecting norepinephrine receptors in the prefrontal cortex.
medications: Guanfacine (Intuniv, Tenex): Extended-release formulation, may help with hyperactivity and impulsivity
Clonidine (Kapvay, Catapres): Can help with hyperactivity, impulsivity, and sleep issues
alpha2.sideEffects: Common side effects: drowsiness, fatigue, low blood pressure, dizziness. These medications should not be stopped abruptly.

finding.title: Finding the Right Medication
points: Medication effectiveness varies significantly between individuals
Finding the right medication and dosage often requires trial and adjustment
Factors to consider: symptom profile, lifestyle, comorbidities, side effect tolerance
Regular follow-ups with your healthcare provider are essential
Dosage may need adjustment over time

monitoring.title: Monitoring & Safety
points: Regular monitoring of blood pressure and heart rate
Tracking height and weight in children
Monitoring for side effects and effectiveness
Discussing any concerns or changes with your doctor
Not sharing medications with others
Storing medications securely

myths.title: Medication Myths vs. Facts
myths: "Once you start medication, you'll need it forever"
"Medications are a 'quick fix' and don't require other treatments"
"All ADHD medications work the same way"
facts: When properly prescribed and monitored, ADHD medications are generally safe and effective
Medications help manage symptoms but don't fundamentally change who you are
Many people can stop or adjust medications as their needs change
Medication is most effective when combined with therapy, behavioral strategies, and lifestyle changes
Different medications work differently; finding the right one is a personalized process

comprehensive.title: Medication as Part of Comprehensive Treatment
comprehensive.description: Medication is often most effective when used as part of a comprehensive treatment plan that may include:
treatments: Behavioral therapy to develop coping strategies
Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) for thought patterns
Executive function coaching for organization skills

talkingToDoctor.title: Talking to Your Healthcare Provider
talkingToDoctor.description: If you're considering medication for ADHD, here are some questions to discuss with your healthcare provider:
questions: What are the potential benefits and risks of medication for my specific situation?
What types of medications are available and how do they differ?
What side effects should I watch for?
How long will it take to see effects?
How will we monitor the medication's effectiveness?
Are there any interactions with other medications or conditions I should know about?
What should I do if I experience side effects?
How long might I need to take medication?
talkingToDoctor.remember: Remember: Open communication with your healthcare provider is essential for safe and effective medication management.

assessment.title: ADHD Assessment
assessment.description: Please answer all 18 questions based on how often you experience each situation.
assessment.question: Question {number}:
questions: How often do you have trouble wrapping up the final details of a project, once the challenging parts have been done?
How often do you have difficulty getting things in order when you have to do a task that requires organization?
How often do you have problems remembering appointments or obligations?
When you have a task that requires a lot of thought, how often do you avoid or delay getting started?
How often do you fidget or squirm with your hands or feet when you have to sit down for a long time?
How often do you feel overly active and compelled to do things, like you were driven by a motor?
How often do you make careless mistakes when you have to work on a boring or difficult project?
How often do you have difficulty keeping your attention when you are doing boring or repetitive work?
How often do you have difficulty concentrating on what people say to you, even when they are speaking to you directly?
How often do you misplace or have difficulty finding things at home or at work?
How often are you distracted by activity or noise around you?
How often do you leave your seat in meetings or other situations in which you are expected to remain seated?
How often do you feel restless or fidgety?
How often do you have difficulty unwinding and relaxing when you have time to yourself?
How often do you find yourself talking too much when you are in social situations?
When you're in a conversation, how often do you find yourself finishing the sentences of the people you are talking to, before they can finish them themselves?
How often do you have difficulty waiting your turn in situations when turn taking is required?
How often do you interrupt others when they are busy?

consistent.title: ⚠️ Symptoms Highly Consistent with ADHD
consistent.description: Four or more marks appear in the darkly shaded boxes within Part A. This indicates symptoms highly consistent with ADHD in adults and further investigation is warranted.

notConsistent.title: ✓ Fewer than 4 dark shaded responses in Part A
notConsistent.description: The screening results do not indicate a high likelihood of ADHD symptoms based on Part A responses.

partB.title: Part B Results (Questions 7-18)
partB.description: The frequency scores on Part B provide additional cues and can serve as further probes into the patient's symptoms. Pay particular attention to marks appearing in the dark shaded boxes. No total score or diagnostic likelihood is utilized for the twelve questions.

cpt.title: Conners Continuous Performance Test 3rd Edition (CPT-3)

instructions.title: Instructions
items: You will see letters appear on the screen one at a time.
Press SPACEBAR or CLICK when you see any letter EXCEPT "X".
Do NOT respond when you see the letter "X".
The assessment will take approximately 14 minutes to complete (360 trials).
Respond as quickly and accurately as possible.
instructions.tip: Tip: Keep your hands ready. You can use either the spacebar or mouse click to respond.

cpt.pressForNonX: Press SPACEBAR or CLICK when you see any letter except "X"

detectability.title: Detectability
detectability.description: Ability to discriminate targets from non-targets: {value}

hitRTByISI.title: Hit Reaction Time by ISI
hitRTByISI.noResponses: No correct responses recorded - cannot calculate reaction times by ISI

hitRTBlockChange.title: Hit Reaction Time Block Change
hitRTBlockChange.noResponses: No correct responses recorded - cannot calculate reaction time changes
hitRTBlockChange.change: Change in reaction time over blocks: {value}ms/block

adhdAnalysis.title: ADHD-Related Performance Analysis
adhdAnalysis.disclaimer: Important Disclaimer: This analysis is for informational purposes only and is not a diagnostic tool. ADHD diagnosis requires comprehensive clinical evaluation by a qualified healthcare professional. Test performance can be influenced by many factors including fatigue, anxiety, motivation, and other conditions.
adhdAnalysis.nextSteps: Next Steps: If you have concerns about attention or impulse control, consider consulting with a healthcare professional who specializes in ADHD assessment. A comprehensive evaluation typically includes clinical interviews, behavioral observations, and may incorporate multiple assessment tools.

tova.title: Test of Variables of Attention (TOVA)

instructions.title: Instructions
items: You will see two types of squares appear on the screen: small and large.
First Half (10.8 minutes): Press SPACEBAR or CLICK when you see a SMALL square. Do NOT respond to large squares.
Second Half (10.8 minutes): Press SPACEBAR or CLICK when you see a LARGE square. Do NOT respond to small squares.
The test will automatically switch to the second half after 10.8 minutes.
Respond as quickly and accurately as possible.
instructions.tip: Tip: Pay attention to the indicator showing which half you're in. The target changes between halves!

tova.pressForSmall: Press SPACEBAR or CLICK for SMALL squares
tova.pressForLarge: Press SPACEBAR or CLICK for LARGE squares

adhdAnalysis.title: ADHD-Related Performance Analysis
adhdAnalysis.disclaimer: Important Disclaimer: This analysis is for informational purposes only and is not a diagnostic tool. ADHD diagnosis requires comprehensive clinical evaluation by a qualified healthcare professional. Test performance can be influenced by many factors including fatigue, anxiety, motivation, and other conditions.
adhdAnalysis.nextSteps: Next Steps: If you have concerns about attention or impulse control, consider consulting with a healthcare professional who specializes in ADHD assessment. A comprehensive evaluation typically includes clinical interviews, behavioral observations, and may incorporate multiple assessment tools.
